Rather than refer you to stuffy official sources, I’ll entertain to offer my personal view of history. “History” as refers to the past (and to some extent also to the future) is not something “real” but rather something mental, a concept or model we have constructed based on information we have gleaned. Thus “history” does not exist in some physical space in time other than our own. History, therefore, is actually a metaphysical structure, which we have created. History is, you may say, only a theory or a conceptual construct. What we do have (which we often mistake for “history”) is only physical artifacts: Textbooks, encyclopedias, diaries, videos, novels, word-of-mouth reports, legends, Scripture… — these are the compendium of the external manifestos of what we call “history.” The true internal “history” is not those written records but the mental construct in the metaphysical realm. The external documents are indeed records, yet these are also subject to opinion, cultural or socioeconomic bias, viewpoint, and even fading and degradation through time. Is a video of an event “history”? No. It is a historical record, yet not the true history. Take JFK’s assassination: What is the “true history”? That would be what actually happened. Yet where is that? When those who are or were in the know all die, what will remain? Their memories will be transferred to the eternal metaphysical realm. Who can then prove what actually happened? Let us suppose there are angels who record everything. These metaphysical entities would know the true history. Yet, who can interview an angel or God and get the true account? No; this would also be a “record” or a “testimony” — again subject to truth or falsehood, personal bias, and other inaccuracies. I remember JFK’s assassination like a flashcube went off in history. I was at Edward’s AFB as a 9-year-old kid. Did it happen? Of course we all know that. But how did it happen? No one can tell for sure….. Did we land on the Moon? I was there! I watched it on TV as a Boy Scout at Camp Goshen. Will I lie? Yet who can really prove that someone didn’t fabricate that, too? At best we have theories: the best possible ones will win out in the social and psychological realms, and make it to the history books. Yet those history books will never be a conclusive final Proof. History, ultimately, abides in the metaphysical realm: Only God truly knows.

History is the study of the past, particularly people and events of the past. History is a pursuit common to all human societies. Human beings have always been interested in the past, for many reasons. History can be a tremendous story, a rolling narrative filled with great personalities and tales of turmoil and triumph. Each passing generation adds its own chapter to history, while reinterpreting and finding new things in those chapters already written. History also gives us a sense of identity; by understanding where we have come from, we can better understand who we are. History provides a sense of context for our lives and our existence, helping us to understand the way things are and how we might approach the future. History teaches us what it means to be human, highlighting the great achievements and disastrous errors of the human race. History also offers hints about how we can organise and manage our societies, for the betterment of all those who live in them.  Those starting out in history often consider history and the past to be the same thing. This is not the case. The past refers to an earlier time, the people and societies who inhabited it and the events that took place there. History describes our attempts to investigate, study and explain the past. It is a subtle difference but an important one. What happened in the past is fixed in time and cannot be changed. History, however, changes regularly. The word “history” and the English word “story” both originate from the Latin historia, meaning a narrative or account of past events. History is itself a collection of thousands of stories about the past, told by many different people. Because there are so many stories, they are often variable, contradictory and conflicting. And like all stories, history is subject to revision and reinterpretation. Each generation looks at the past through its own eyes. It applies different standards, priorities and values and reaches different conclusions about the past. The study of how history differs and has changed over time is called historiography. Like historical narratives themselves, our understanding of what history is and the shape it should take is flexible and open to debate. For as long as people have studied history, historians have presented different ideas about how the past should be studied, constructed, written and interpreted. As a consequence, historians may approach history in different ways, using different ideas and methods and focusing on or prioritising different aspects. The following paragraphs discuss several popular theories of history: “History is the study of great individuals”  Plutarch According to the ancient Greek writer Plutarch, true history is the study of great leaders and innovators. Prominent individuals shape the course of history through their personality, strength of character, ambition, abilities, leadership or creativity. Plutarch’s histories were written almost as biographies or ‘life and times’ stories of these great individuals. They explained how the actions of these great figures shaped the course of their nations or societies. Plutarch’s approach served as a model for many later historians. It is sometimes referred to as ‘top-down’ history because of its focus on rulers or leaders. One advantage of this approach is its accessibility and relative easiness. It is often much easier to research and write about individuals than more complex factors, such as social movements or long-term changes. The Plutarchian focus on individuals can also be more interesting and accessible to readers. The main problem with this approach is that it can sidestep, simplify or overlook historical factors and conditions that do not emanate from important individuals, such as popular unrest or economic changes. “History is the study of the ‘winds of change'”  The Berlin Wall falls in 1989, a ‘winds of change’ moment Other historians have focused less on individuals and taken a more thematic approach, looking at factors and forces that produce significant historical change. Some focus on what might broadly be described as the ‘winds of change’: powerful ideas, forces and movements that shape or affect how people live, work and think. These great ideas and movements are often initiated or driven by influential people – but they become much larger forces for change. As the ‘winds of change’ grow, they shape or influence political, economic and social events and conditions. An example of a notable ‘wind of change’ was Christianity, which shaped government, society and social customs in medieval Europe. Another was the European Enlightenment, which undermined old ideas about politics, religion and the natural world; this triggered a long period of curiosity, education and innovation. Marxism emerged in the late 19th century and grew to challenge the old order in Russia, China and elsewhere, shaping government and society in those nations. The Age of Exploration, the Industrial Revolution, decolonisation in the mid-1900s and the winding back of eastern European communism in the late-1900s are all tangible examples of the ‘winds of change’. “History is the study of challenge and response” Some historians, such as the British writer Arnold Toynbee (1889-1975), believed historical change is driven by challenges and responses. All civilisations are defined not just by their leadership or conditions but by how they respond to difficult problems or crises. These challenges take many forms. They can be physical, environmental, economic or ideological; they can derive from internal pressures or external factors; they can come from their own people or from outsiders. The survival and success of a civilisation are determined by how it responds to these challenges. This itself often depends on its people and how creative, resourceful, adaptable and flexible they are. Human history is filled with many tangible examples of challenge and response. Many nations have been confronted with powerful rivals, wars, natural disasters, economic slumps, new ideas, emerging political movements and internal dissent. The process of colonisation, for example, involved major challenges, both for colonising settlers and native inhabitants. Economic changes, such as new technologies and increases or decreases in trade, have created challenges in the form of social changes or class tensions. “History is the study of dialectics”  Karl Marx, creator of the ‘material dialectic’ In philosophy, dialectics is a process where two or more parties with vastly different viewpoints reach a compromise and mutual agreement. The theory of dialectics was applied to history by German philosopher Georg Hegel (1770-1831). Hegel suggested that most historical changes and outcomes were driven by dialectic interaction. According to Hegel, for every thesis (a proposition or ‘idea’) there exists an antithesis (a reaction or ‘opposite idea’). The thesis and antithesis encounter or struggle, from which emerges a synthesis (a ‘new idea’). This ongoing process of struggle and development reveals new ideas and new truths to humanity. The German philosopher Karl Marx (1818-1883) was a student of Hegel and incorporated the Hegelian dialectic into his own theory of history – with one important distinction. According to Marx, history was shaped by the ‘material dialectic’: the struggle between economic classes. Marx believed the ownership of capital and wealth underpinned most social structures and interactions. All classes struggle and push to improve their economic conditions, Marx wrote, usually at the expense of other classes. Marx’s material dialectic was reflected in his stinging criticisms of capitalism, a political and economic system where the capital-owning classes control production and exploit the worker, in order to maximise their profits. “History is the story of the unexpected”  Franz Ferdinand’s murder in 1914, an unexpected but pivotal moment in history Some historians believe history is shaped by the accidental, the surprising and the unexpected. While history and historical change certainly follow patterns, they can also be unpredictable and chaotic. Despite our fascination with timelines and linear progression, history does not always follow a clear and expected path. The past is filled with unexpected incidents, surprises and accidental discoveries. Some of these have unleashed historical forces and changes that could not be predicted, controlled or stopped. A few have come at pivotal times and served as the ignition or ‘flashpoint’ for changes of great significance. The discovery of gold has triggered gold rushes that shaped the future of entire nations. In June 1914 Archduke Franz Ferdinand’s car took a different route through Sarajevo and passed an aimless Gavrilo Princip, a confluence of events that led to World War I. American historian Daniel Boorstin (1914-2004), an exponent of this fascination with historical accidents, claimed that if Cleopatra’s nose had been shorter, thus diminishing her beauty, then the history of the world might have been radically differen

History is a narration of the events which have happened among mankind, including an account of the rise and fall of nations, as well as of other great changes which have affected the political and social condition of the human race.—John J. Anderson. 1876. A Manual of General History. History is the study of the human past as it is described in the written documents left by human beings. The past, with all its decisions completed, its participants dead and its history told, is what the general public perceives as the immutable bedrock on which we historians and archaeologists stand. But as purveyors of the past, we recognize that the bedrock is really quicksand, that bits of the story are yet untold, and that what has been told comes tainted by the conditions of what we are today. If a science of history were achieved, it would, like the science of celestial mechanics, make possible the calculable prediction of the future in history. It would bring the totality of historical occurrences within a single field and reveal the unfolding future to its last end, including all the apparent choices made and to be made. It would be omniscience. The creator of it would possess the attributes ascribed by the theologians to God. The future once revealed, humanity would have nothing to do except to await its doom.

History is a useful narrative constructed from what we know about the past. Let me unpack that bit by bit. "History is a ... narrative..." History is not an accurate reproduction of the past and it is not all of the facts. History is a story (as the word indicates). We know the names and home towns all of the soldiers involved in D-Day. We know what many of them ate that day. We know the technical specs of their weapons, who designed, and who manufactured them. We know the logistics of getting them to the beach, the support efforts, and the casualties. To write a history of that day, the historian has to pick and choose through all of the raw data--the facts--to decide what is necessary to tell the story they want to tell. "History is ... useful..." No historian is completely random in picking their narrative. Again, look at military history. A narrative based on the same data/facts might describe a glorious victory, a unredeemed tragedy, or illustrate some aspect of the human condition. Facts and interpretation are two different things. This is why conservatives get so upset about how history is taught in the schools. Each new generation of historians reinterprets the same facts in the light of their experiences. Conservatives want history to be carved in stone. Facts are facts. History isn't facts; history is interpretation of facts. "History is ... constructed from what we know..." We can't know everything. This is obvious in the far past where we take every tiny data point and try to squeeze as much information as we can from it. Every decade or so we have an earthshaking discovery in ancient history. Here is a city that dominated this trade route for three centuries and this changes everything we thought we knew about the cities on either end of that trade route. Even in something as information rich as the D-Day example, there is an enormous amount we don't know. What were the conversations that led to important decisions? Who knew what and when did they now it? It's an historian's cliche to refer to history as a jigsaw puzzle with missing pieces, and no box to show us what the picture should look like, and no edge pieces, and a few handfuls of pieces from other puzzles added, and a hyperactive cat in the house, and half the pieces are wet... and that's why we love it.

Following on from some of the earlier comments, there are three major ways in which the term “history” is used. First, as anything and everything that has happened in the past. There is a history of everything: of Easter Island, of the Vietnam War, of marbles, of fondue, of the American musical, of baseball in Asia . . . Whatever happened. It can include material normally studied under the heading of anthropology, sociology, literature, music, art, science, whatever; if it happened in the past, it has a history. It’s all of life - at least all of life up until the last few years/months/days. Second, as the _study_ of what happened in the past, not so much “what happened?” as “how do we [or how do others] understand what happened?” Sometimes this is distinguished from history by capitalization [A History of the United States]; some of it is subsumed under “historiography,” which is the history of historical writing. In this sense, we are often looking closely at evidence, at the sources that supply us with our understanding of the past. If the sources are lacking, our History may be rather thin. So we might say that the History of the Philippines before the 16th century is rather sketchy, in that we don’t know a lot about it, but that doesn’t mean the history of the Philippines [lower case] wasn’t as real and full of incident and culture as the history of other places. It just means that we don’t know a lot about it! Third, as the formal study of “History” in our society, particularly in schools and universities, but also in books and TV programs and the like. This tends to be restricted to certain aspects of the past, such as politics (lists of kings and presidents, wars and treaties, etc.), macro-economics (The Great Depression), etc. It will also normally have some chronological limits, e.g., American History from the Revolution to the Civil War. (There was once a convention in some universities that “History” only came up to some date in the not-all-that-recent past: before any of us were alive, or the date at which the diplomatic archives were opened. After that, it was implied, there were only Current Events.) In that sense, if someone claims to know “History” (or asks if you know it), the subject is likely to be not “everything that ever happened,” but “some of the political events and people in the past that we in our society acknowledge to be important,” e.g., Kings, Presidents, Battles, Inventions, etc. Such restriction is arbitrary, but since it is impossible to know everything about everything, there is a necessity to limit and focus our vision and try to understand _something_, which we hope and trust will be something of importance. I couldn’t offer a course on “History” without a narrower subject matter, unless I was trying to teach what is sometimes called “historical methods,” e.g., how we select and analyze evidence. So what you will find in a “history textbook” is a selection of the facts and themes - among literally millions of others - that the author thought were worth studying; no matter how well selected these are, and how long the textbook is, you should always remember that FAR more was left out than included. And that is how it has to be. FWIW, Ken Burns is the great presenter of TV “History” in our time, and while his series on the Civil War is justly acclaimed, and right in the mainstream of “American History,” his features on Baseball and National Parks - which are usually omitted from “American History” - are just as good. Enjoy!

The word “history” has two basic meanings. But there are three terms that need to be discussed. The example of a game of football can help us understand it all.  The two basic meanings of the word “history”: History can refer to those things, events and so forth that actually happened in the past (Latin: res gestae, meaning “things done” ). Let’s call this history(1).History can also refer to the analysis/investigation of past things, events and so forth (Latin: historia rerum gestarum, meaning “history of things done”). We are talking here about the professional writings and productions of historians. Let’s call this history(2).History(2) is also called historiography.But: the term historiography can also refer to the meta-discipline that is the theory/philosophy of history, meaning the reflection and contemplation on the nature and quality of history(2). Consider a game of football: you are lingering in the stadium after witnessing a great game, possibly the best you have ever seen. You and your buddies are passionately discussing every single detail, each of you offering a variety of rich descriptions all the while relating them to the game in its entirety. You even ponder the game’s significance in relationship to the whole season, perhaps even the past decade of football. During the discussion you come to realize that there are several seemingly mutually exclusive interpretations at play, or at least each one of you is drawing out different meanings by means of highlighting different aspects of the game, of the teams and of the past decade. You think to yourself: “Why don’t we agree with each other? Louis is making sense, displaying a controlled but tangible passion. Rinus, being the oldest, is definitely dropping a few wisdom bombs. I don’t understand a word Johan is saying, but I feel like he’s probably right. Besides, he used to be pretty decent himself at the whole football thing.” You realize that analyzing a football game is not that straightforward: you, Louis, Rinus and Johan have a different approach to the same particular game. However, this realization does not trump your more important realization that the game is worth discussing anyway. Besides, there are quite some things you do agree on. So when history is likened to a game of football, we get this: History(1) is the actual game.History(2) is the post-game analysis/documentation/reporting by you and your buddies, news outlets, sports magazines, websites and so forth.(the meta-discipline) Historiography reflects on the post-game analyses produced by the different authors/sources, considering their presuppositions, structuring and legitimacy.In conclusion: history(2) is a portrayal of history(1) in a book, article, encyclopedia, documentary and so forth. Historiography (in the meta-discipline sense) reflects on the way history(2) is being done.

When I first started studying history in college, my favorite professor said this: “There's no truth in history, only perspective" While history is about what happened in the past, it's not like geology or paleontology. History is not a subject of science. It is a subject of humanities. And because history is written by men, the study of history comes in two folds: first the study of what happened in the past, second the study of how such events were recorded. And when we read historical records, we always need to be mindful about who wrote it, when this record was written, under what circumstances, what resources the historian had and what point the historian intended to make. Yes, all historians inevitably make points in their book, consciously or unconsciously. There's no objective history. I was very lucky to meet a professor who not only understood this, but made sure her class reflected this concept. She never really followed the book. She expected you to read everything in the textbook and her lectures always gave students different perspectives to think about. Take Giorgio Vasari for example, Vasari is widely regarded as the first art historian because of his influential book Lives of the Most Excellent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects (or in short: The Lives). Every student of Renaissance history reads this book (or at least reads part of it). But Vasari was also notoriously biased in favor of the Florentine school of art, and the guy had the worst habit of recording rumors and gossips as “real", and sometimes he made up stuff. This is even worse if one were to study Chinese history. Yes, we have the longest continuous written history in the world; yes we are the only civilization that specifically set up a government position to record history; yes our culture emphasizes the recording of history so even more than the central government, many provinces, counties, villages and large families maintain local history. But, they're all biased and should be read as such. It's nice to give historians government positions, but that means that what the historian ended up recording was scrutinized by the government. While there was integrity and honor among the literati—who were obligated by their personal principles to write truthfully—in practice, the embarrassing actions of emperors might have been omitted, and false information might have been made up to justify a poor decision. If a new dynasty replaced the old one, the historians from the new dynasty would often engage in smear campaigns to legitimize the new dynasty. To study history we must take information from different sources and try to piece together a more 3 dimensional view of history. I often see historical studies like detective work or jigsaw puzzles. You can't trust your witnesses, you need to find missing pieces. But in the end, there's no truth in history. We don't know what happened. Even people who experience the historical event don't know what happened. All we can say is “we think this is most likely scenario because of this and this and that record, but we're not 100% sure.” We'll never be 100% sure. And I think that's the charm of history, that there's always some mystery waiting for you to discover.

History is set of culturally-bound narratological rules and tropes that we trot out when we need to make sense of the world (in general or in specific). History gives us the illusion that our lives play out in some grand drama of good against evil (or to reference the excellent Mr. Trejo below) freedom against non-freedom. It’s to make us feel better, I think. History then is the pattern we make. It’s the story of freedom vs non-freedom, bourgeois vs proletariat, christian vs heathen that we tell ourselves to make a coherent and usually happy story out of what is often violent, random chaos (often with us as the suffering hero). I think this explains the popularity of questions about warfare on Quora. Warfare is inconceivably horrible, but as a species we keep doing it. Discussion of strategies or tactics or great leaders use historical narrative to hide the nastiness of the business. The historical discussion focuses our attention away from the blood and suffering and towards abstractions that might as well be annotations of a chess game or a play-by-play. It also may desensitize us to the horrible fact that we still war….

History (from Greek ἱστορία, historia, meaning "inquiry, knowledge acquired by investigation") is the study of the past, particularly how it relates to humans. It is anumbrella term that relates to past events as well as the memory, discovery, collection, organization, presentation, and interpretation of information about these events. Scholars who write about history are called historians. Events occurring prior to written record are considered prehistory. History can also refer to the academic discipline which uses a narrative to examine and analyse a sequence of past events, and objectively determine the patterns of cause and effect that determine them. Historians sometimes debate the nature of history and its usefulness by discussing the study of the discipline as an end in itself and as a way of providing "perspective" on the problems of the present. Stories common to a particular culture, but not supported by external sources (such as the tales surrounding King Arthur), are usually classified as cultural heritage or legends, because they do not show the "disinterested investigation" required of the discipline of history. Herodotus, a 5th-century BC Greek historian is considered within the Western tradition to be the "father of history", and, along with his contemporary Thucydides, helped form the foundations for the modern study of human history. Their works continue to be read today, and the gap between the culture-focused Herodotus and the military-focused Thucydides remains a point of contention or approach in modern historical writing. In Asia, a state chronicle, the Spring and Autumn Annals was known to be compiled from as early as 722 BC although only 2nd century BC texts survived. Ancient influences have helped spawn variant interpretations of the nature of history which have evolved over the centuries and continue to change today. The modern study of history is wide-ranging, and includes the study of specific regions and the study of certain topical or thematical elements of historical investigation. Often history is taught as part of primary and secondary education, and the academic study of history is a major discipline in university studies.

History takes a discipline-based view of history as a process of inquiry with its own methods and procedures, based on the analysis and interpretation of evidence. An inquiry approach encourages students to pose questions and seek answers, to locate, analyse and interpret evidence, to discover and explain different perspectives and interpretations about the past and to develop and substantiate their own interpretations, based on evidence. So, history is not simply a body of content to be transmitted to students, nor a set of concepts, methods and skills to be taught in isolation, but an approach that brings the two together. Students develop historical knowledge and understanding by applying historical concepts, methods and skills to their investigations of aspects of the past.
